data: Situation-Aware Mobile Platform for Airport Collaborative Decision-Making

The economic costs of aircraft delays in Europe have been estimated at 1.25Bn Euros per year. Aircraft delays also result in environmental costs: aircraft holding or queuing with engines on, resulting in excess environmental emissions and air quality or noise impact, unnecessary ground movements and activation of auxiliary power units.
Airport IQ will develop a mobile information sharing system connecting back-end A-CDM systems with mobile devices (smartphones, tablets and other wearable devices) carried by ground staff. The system will provide the right information at the right place and time to the right people, making it easier for planners to make optimal use of resources. This will help reduce primary and reactionary delays, improve the reliability of estimates, and allow airlines to make smarter decisions about turnaround buffers, that will be shorter than before.  Airport IQ will also offer a simple way to simulate turnaround activities, making it possible to run operational exercises using the same mobile tools, which will simplify and improve the quality of training, as well as providing the basis for designing longer-term improvements in ground handling processes. 
The solution has the potential to create significant economic and environmental savings for the entire air transport value chain, as demonstrated by pilot trials  to be organized in 3 European airports (Lisboa, Heathrow and Targu Mures), involving real end-users (i.e. ground handling and other airport staff) using “live” onsite data. The project duration is 24 months and the requested EC contribution is 2M Euros.

CHS, Centrum Humanberuflicher Schulen des Bundes Villach, is a secondary vocational school providing higher education entrance qualification and comprises the following specializations: 
- Höhere Lehranstalt für wirtschaftliche Berufe (business administration)
- Höhere Lehranstalt für Kommunikation und Mediendesign (communication and media)
- Höhere Lehranstalt für Kunst und Gestaltung (arts)
- Höhere Lehranstalt für Modedesign und Grafik (fashion design)

Within the project "CHS explores Europe" 26 CHS students will complete their internship in various EU countries. The duration depends on the students' specialisation and varies between four and twelve weeks. All mobilities take place between 1 June and 28 September 2014. The receiving organisations are located in the UK, Italy, Malta and Germany. They are both long time partners of the sending organisation as well as new contacts thanks to the students' initiative.

19 of the students participating in the current CHS project attend the specialisation "Höhere Lehranstalt für wirtschaftliche Berufe", i. e. business administration and have a solid education in business, foreign languages, tourism and management. Five participants specialising in fashion design do their four-week internship in a fashion institute in Milan. Their education at CHS includes collection development and computer graphics. The remaining two CHS specialisations, communication/media and arts send one student each who will work in an advertising agency and a fashion studio. They have been especially trained in web design/publishing and textile/industrial design.
In the course of the project the 26 participating students are going to develop knowledge, skills and competences that qualify them for the following professions: restaurant management assistant, dressmaker, media designer and product designer.

All professional experiences gathered during the mobility activities are assessed, validated and accredited in the interchange between participants, receiving organisations and CHS. Therefore we apply the following ECVET documents: Learning Agreement, Memorandum of Understanding and Personal Transcript. Furthermore, the Europass Mobility document will be issued for all 26 participants.

As a secondary vocational school in the heart of the Alps-Adriatic region and located in the boarder area between Slovenia, Italy and Austria, CHS Villach is aiming at combining the theoretical and practical education of our students with professional training in a broader European context. CHS puts great emphasis on an education towards a sense of European citizenship and identity. The project "CHS explores Europe" aims at creating a network across different sectors - private, institutional/professional (schools and enterprises) and intercultural. The mobility activities of our students are clearly characterised through their orientation towards precise learning outcomes in the students' respective specialisations (see above) and most of all the sustainability of their results. Hereby "CHS explores Europe" wants to spark the students' passion for Lifelong Learning.

Technology is now an integral part of everyday life and there are key skills that are imperative for children to learn that they will use in their personal and professional lives. This project is a way to begin to develop these skills with our students, preparing them for the future career market but it also offers valuable opportunities to expand our pedagogical practice and our own professional competences. As part of a staff meeting and through discussion with our Computing lead teacher we have identified as a school that we are not using the equipment we have to its fullest effect and that we want to develop staff confidence in using IT more creatively across a range of subjects.The opportunity to collaborate and learn from our European partners, will help us improve our future cooperation both as teachers and as future workers, using our languages in a meaningful way and developing our understanding of the huge potential ICT has in our lives. This project has 4 partners in England, Italy, Poland and Spain. We are all new partners and are keen to develop our skills, knowledge and understanding together.We are planning a 2 year project including teacher training and job shadowing.During the first year of the project (2016/2017) there will be a focus activity each term. In the first term teachers will participate in a course called 'Digital Classroom'. On returning from the course the teachers will develop a 'How to guide' that can be used a training tool with staff and can be shared on our etwinning webspace. This can ultimately be shared with a wider audience when we publish the space as a website. In the first year we will also work on producing digital postcards and a cartoon of a traditional tale across the partner schools.During the second year of the project (2017/2018) there will be a second wave of teachers attending training for the 'Digital Classroom'. The expectation will be that a second 'How to guide' will be produced as a training tool for staff, focusing on different skills. This will also be shared on the etwinning webspace. We will also work on producing a mini movie about day to day life in school and make a movie based on traditional dances using green screens.Assessment and dissemination are two of our main concerns whilst carrying out the project. All of the people involved, meaning parents, teachers and pupils, will evaluate an disseminate what has been done through different media. We will also carry out a clear audit of current skills/expertise across staff andpupils before the project begins and complete the same audit at the end of the project so that we have a clear  measure for impact.The impact will also be visible on the work published on the etwinning space and the 'How to guides' produced for staff training. We will review our curriculum during the project to ensure skills acquired whilst we are collaborating with our partners are embedded as part of our ongoing curriculum. This will ensure that these skills continue to be taught and developed long after the project has finished. Longer term benefits are the increased confidence of staff and pupils to be creative and imaginative in their use of IT. There should be an increased use of the equipment available to staff and a tangible improvement in their confidence levels to use it.

La tecnología es hoy en día una parte integral de la vida diaria y hay habilidades clave que los niños tienen que aprender ya que las usarán en su vida personal y profesional. Este proyecto es una manera de comenzar a desarrollar estas habilidades con nuestros estudiantes, preparándolos para el futuro mercado laboral, pero también nos ofrece a nosotros oportunidades para expandir nuestra práctica pedagógica y nuestras propias competencias profesionales. Nos hemos dado cuenta que, como escuela, quizás no estamos usando el equipamiento del que disponemos en su máximo potencial y que queremos desarrollar la confianza del personal en el uso de las Tecnologías de la Información de una manera más creativa a través de las distintas asignaturas.La oportunidad de colaborar y aprender de nuestros socios europeos nos ayudará a mejorar nuestra futura colaboración tanto como maestros/as como futuros trabajadores, usando nuestras lenguas de una forma significativa y aumentando nuestra comprensión del enorme potencial que las Tecnologías de la Información y la Comunicación tienen en nuestras vidas.Este proyecto tiene 4 socios en España, Inglaterra, Polonia e Italia. Somos nuevos socios y estamos dispuestos a desarrollar juntos nuestras habilidades, conocimientos y comprensión.Estamos planeando un proyecto de dos años de duración, incluyendo cursos estructurados y períodos de observación de buenas prácticas.Durante el primer año del proyecto (2016/17) habrá una actividad principal en cada trimestre. En el primer trimestre los maestros/as participarán en un curso llamado "Digital Classroom". A la vuelta del curso los maestros/as desarrollarán un "How to guide" que puede ser usado como una herramienta de formación para el profesorado y que puede ser compartido en la plataforma eTwinning. Esto a su vez puede ser expandido en último término a una audiencia mayor cuando publiquemos este espacio como página web. En este primer año también trabajaremos en la realización de postales digitales y en un boceto de un cuento tradicional entre las escuelas socias.A lo largo del segundo año (2017/18) habrá otro grupo de profesores que asistirán a la formación del curso "Digital Classroom". La expectativa será que un segundo "How to guide" sea producido como herramienta de formación del personal, centrándose en habilidades diferentes. Éste también será compartido en eTwinning. También trabajaremos en la producción de un pequeño corto sobre la vida diaria en la escuela y en la realización de una película basada en bailes tradicionales de los distintos países implicados en el proyecto.La evaluación y la difusión son dos de las preocupaciones principales a la hora de llevar a cabo nuestro proyecto. Todas las personas implicadas, incluyendo padres/madres, maestros/as, niños/as, evaluarán y difundirán lo que haya sido hecho a través de distintos medios. También llevaremos a cabo una auditoria de las habilidades y experiencias actuales entre el profesorado y el alumnado antes de que el proyecto comience y repetiremos la misma autoría al final del proyecto, de manera que tengamos una medida clara del impacto del mismo.Este efecto e impacto será también visible en el trabajo publicado en el espacio de eTwinning y en las guías ("How to guides") producidas en los cursos de formación del profesorado. Revisaremos nuestro currículo durante el proyecto para garantizar las habilidades adquiridas durante la colaboración con nuestros socios y las integraremos como parte del currículo que sigamos desarrollando posteriormente. Esto asegurará que estas habilidades continúen siendo enseñadas y desarrolladas mucho después de que el proyecto haya finalizado. Los beneficios a largo plazo que se pretenden son el incremento de la confianza del profesorado y el alumnado para ser creativos e imaginativos en su uso de las Tecnologías de la Información y la Comunicación. Deberá haber un incremento en el uso del equipamiento disponible para el profesorado y una mejora tangible en sus niveles de confianza para utilizarlo.
Raising standards through creativity and the outdoor curriculum

The aim of this project is to encourage and inspire pupils and teaching staff through positive outdoor experiences. By participating in engaging, motivating and achievable tasks and activities outside of the classroom each participant has an opportunity to develop intrinsic motivation, sound emotional and social skills. Due to changes in society and the rise in the use of technology, many children do not make the most of the world outside of their classrooms and homes. This project is a way to further develop these skills with our students, preparing them for the future career market but it also offers valuable opportunities to expand our pedagogical practice  and our own professional competences. As part of a staff meeting and through discussion with our locality colleagues we have identified as a school that we are not using the outdoors to its fullest effect and that we want to develop staff confidence in using the outdoors more creatively across a range of subjects. 
Over the two years, training and job shadowing will be targeted so  members of staff who will have most impact from their training and members of staff who would most benefit from the training will be selected. Groups of participating staff will be carefully selected so that there is a balance of experience and language skills. The selection process will be clear and transparent so that all members of staff are clear why and how successful staff are selected.
The opportunity to collaborate and learn from our European partners, will help us improve our future cooperation both as teachers and as future workers, using our languages in a meaningful way and developing our understanding of the huge potential the outdoor curriculum can develop in children's lives.
The project partners in England, Greece, Spain, Portugal, Slovakia, Romania and Italy are keen to develop our skills, knowledge and understanding together. All partners are new except for England and Greece. We would like to work together again as during our Comenius project together, which finished 2 years ago,  we identified these skills as a priority for both of our schools. We are planning a 2 year project including teacher training and job shadowing.
During the first year of the project (2017/2018) there will be a focus area each term. In the first year we will also participate in two 'Outdoor Curriculum' courses which will focus on different skills. On returning from the courses the teachers will develop 'Outdoor Curriculum' guides that can be used as a training tool with staff and that can be shared on our etwinning space.  This can ultimately be shared with a wider audience when we publish the space as a website. In the first year we will also develop literacy skills during an 'Enchanted Woodland' project, develop a health and wellbeing project and there will also be a Science focus.
During the second year of the project (2018/2019) we will review all the training we have received in the Spring and Summer term of the first year and ensure that we incorporate the skills and practices into our projects. Our focus areas will be Maths in the Outdoors, Art in the Outdoors and caring for our Environment.
Assessment and dissemination are two of our main concerns whilst carrying out the project. All of the people involved, meaning parents, teachers and pupils will evaluate and disseminate what has been done through different media. We will also carry out a clear audit of current skills/expertise across staff and pupils before the project begins and complete the same audit at the end of the project so we have a clear measure for impact.
The impact will also be visible on the work published on the etwinning space and the 'Outdoor Curriculum' guides produced for staff training. We will review our curriculum during the project to ensure skills acquired whilst we are collaborating with our partners are embedded as part of our ongoing curriculum. This will ensure that these skills continue to be taught and developed long after the project has finished. Longer term benefits are the increased confidence of staff and pupils to be creative and imaginative in their use of the 'Outdoor Curriculum'.  There should be an increased use of the outdoors for teaching and learning and a tangible improvement in teachers' confidence levels. We should also see an improvement in the childrens' confidence when outdoors and a child centred approach to teaching the outdoor curriculum where pupil voice is strong.

Project title: Variation within the norm

Coordinator for the project: Elaine Björneskog and Jenny Andreen
Organization: Bäckskolan
Address: Konstruktörsgatan 104, 581 37 Linköping, Sweden
Website: http://www.linkoping.se/backskolan

Project information:

Identification: 910128303
Start date: 1/9 2018
End date: 31/8 2020

3 partner schools where job shadowing occurs:
Instituto Comprensivo "G Maiti", Fauglia (Pi) (Italy) - is a leading school in Italy in differentiated learning and the school is working on an educational project called "Senza Zaino". The main components of the project are: assessment / self-assessment, differentiated teaching, golden rules and collegial cooperation.
Langley Green Primary School (U.K) - a multicultural school with many newly arrived students. The school has received the International Schools Award 2015.
 Publiczina Szkola Podstawowa n. 11, Opole (Poland) - this school has high reputation and is considered to be one of the most successful schools in Opole.

Bäckskolan
Bäckskolan is a multicultural school where almost all pupils have a mother tongue other than Swedish. Many students who come to our school lack or have very short school background, as have the pupils' guardians. Therefore, the "bringing up mission" is very distinct and part of the daily work at Bäckskolan. All staff at our school consider it important to have a consensus on educational arrangements, social activities and how to best use the guardians' experiences and knowledge.

The main purpose of the project is to create a consensus about differentiated learning at Bäckskolan, so that the school eventually can profile itself as a school where variation is within the norm. We hope that Bäckskolan can become a school that inspires other schools nationally and internationally.
Differentiated learning is complex and hence we have chosen to focus on the following points:
- Alternative learning tools
- Intercultural approach
- Different media forms
- Enable previous understanding
- See each student
- Challenging tasks
- Create creative learning environments
- Community-oriented activities
- Cooperative learning methods
- Pupil activity in teaching
- High expectations
- Feedback
- Strategies
- Reflection
- Assessment - self-assessment
- Teaching that makes students want to learn
- Especially talented students
These items form the basis of the observation schedule that will be used for job shading as well as starting points for our evaluation.

The ERASMUS project EDUCATION FOR FUTURE originates from the school staff's decision to form exact guidelines for our school's development. We will follow these guidelines and they will influence significantly the raise of quality of our students' knowledge, their creativity, linguistic competence and last but not least their integrated development. These guidelines are:
• developing digital competences,
• promoting a healthy lifestyle of students, their parents and staff members,
• encouraging intercultural integration and raising the level of linguistic competences.

Cirila Kosmača Primary School Piran was the first UNESCO school in Slovenia and it was also in the first cycle of Healthy Schools project. We share years of experience with our partner schools and other organizations through various international projects that include all students and teachers at our school. We are very proud of our interdisciplinary weeks during which we study a particular topic through all school subjects and successeful ETWINNING and other projects.
As a Healthy School we try to follow the topics and goals of Healthy Schools Project. In the school year 2018/19 we will celebrate the 25th anniversary of our membership in Healthy Schools Project. This is a very important event for our school  and thus we decided to pay attention to the topics of promoting a healthy lifestyle. In agreement with our partner school Sekundarschule Fürstenberg from Germany, which also tries to raise the quality level of Healthy Schools Project activities, we will focus on the following themes: FOOD, EXERCISE and MENTAL HEALTH.

Beside a healthy lifestyle we will seek other methods of teaching ICT, LANGUAGES, INTERCULTURAL LEARNING, the ways of introducing topics into curricula of individual subjects and new, innovative ways of teaching these contents to our students. Our partner school Langley Green Primary School from Great Britain was chosen as a school with rich experience in teaching ICT. Being a school with many immigrants the nature of work is different from other schools and it coincides with UNESCO goals.

The most important topics of this project are:
• food, exercise and mental health,
• ICT,
• motivation, communication practices, language through culture, various teaching tools.

European connections, partnership, projects, training and the related new acquired knowledge and international experience in authentic environment are some guidelines at our school. Our school is located in the bilingual area where Italian is a second language and it represents part of our cultural heritage. The knowledge of a second language is important for the future of our students and better adaptation to the requirements of the European Union, developing multilingualism means acquiring different skills.

With the help of the acquired knowledge we want to influence our students as future active citizens who will be acquainted with our common history of European Union, will be able to communicate in intercultural dialogue, will be computer literate, will value health and exercise, will be acquainted with global and environmental problems, will be able to accept difference and who will think and act locally and globally. The project on mobility will help to know foreign education systems. We are going to try new methods of intercultural learning, ways of entering its contents into the curricula of individual subjects and seeking innovative ways of teaching. The acquired knowledge and experience will thus go beyond the boundaries of our school. The openness of our school to the local and wider environment is essential and one of our goals. Raising the level of teaching will be the foundation of our rich creativity and vision for the future.

Claves hacia la excelencia; TIC y nuevas metodologías

Pre-school and primary school (3-12 years old) located in a village that has around 10,000 inhabitants.
 There are 394 students distributed between two group-classes at each. Our students’ families are from low socio cultural status backgrounds. There are 32 teachers working in the school.
 
The idea of this project arises while doing the Erasmus KA2 project, which ends in August 2018. During this project we have introduced new methodologies (CLIL, Peer-learning, Flipped classrooms). From this experience and its positive impact, due to its good results and the teachers’ commitment, arises the necessity to go further and implement this new measures in the school.
 
Our main objectives during the following 4 years:  Internationalize our school, enhance our students and teachers’ ICT skills, and develop our students’ entrepreneurial spirit by working through European collaborative projects, develop students’ personal autonomy and broaden their horizons and allow them to improve their motivation towards learning. Enhancement of our teachers’ and students’ Web 2.0. tools competence, usage of innovative methodologies such as CLIL, Gamified lessons, Escape Classrooms, Webquests, Peer-learning, Flipper classrooms, robotics in Science… In order to achieve this aim we need to train our teachers’ staff in these fields. Having a good command of ICT and new methodologies it is mandatory so as to engage our students.
 
During the first and second term of our first year’s project, we are going to realize five Job Shadowings. The teachers involved in this project are some of the permanent employee and one from the Senior Management Team (management and organisation).
Both training courses will be realized during July of the second year and they will last 6-12 days.
Seven teachers will be trained, each one of them in a different field of methodology or in the usage of ICT tools and later they will teach the rest of the teachers’ staff of our school.
 
Activities to be done:
The year before the beginning of the project: free English language courses at the same school for the teachers who are going to do the training and also for those who are eager to improve their English skills.
A promoting team will be created as well.
Once we have found the schools where we are going to attend a job shadowing, we will plan the stay in order to take the most out of it.
A work plan is going to be done so as to prepare the stay, to evaluate the results, to introduce any necessary changes or recommendations that our partners might suggest us.
Before we do the training course (that will last 6-12 days) we are going to work on each methodology in order to widen our vision and knowledge about the field and at the same time knowing in advance what doubts do we have.

The following step is the courses and the job shadowing.

Once we will have finished, we are going to held observations between teachers so everyone will have the opportunity to learn from the participant teachers in the project.
The Senior Management Team will ask lesson plans monthly where there will be reflected the new methodologies. Video tutorials will be recorded at school in order to show and train new teachers in our school and at the same time, to spread our project.
Hopefully our teachers will learn enough how to implement ICT tools and new methodologies so as to help the rest of our teachers’ staff apply this knowledge in their lessons. We will continue with our schools’ internationalisation thanks to our new partners and eTwinning projects. Better academic results, higher students’ confidence and autonomy, openness towards other cultures and coexistence.
Between mid-term and long-term period, one of the impacts of this project will be the improvement of core subjects and English academic results in Key Competences tests.
Our school will benefit from this project as well regarding our academic results and teachers motivation. This methodological change will give us visibility among others schools in our region.
Large streams from little fountains flow

Looking at the social and economical situation, we agreed on the fact that employability must be worked throughout the compulsory education, pupils to be able to find, maintain and improve a job in their future. 
This project is a way to develop six main specific skills with our students, preparing them for the future labour market, but also to enlarge our pedagogical practice and our own professional competences, using these main skills to product and share innovative methodologies.

 The European cooperation, and by this way the meeting of different educative systems, will help us improve our future cooperation both as teachers and as future workers, speaking foreign language in a meaningful way and developing a constant awareness of ICT possibilities. Our experiment sharing is not going to stay between our partnership because intellectual outputs will be created and broadcast.
This project gather together seven partners from Spain (main coordinator), France, Poland, Italy, Germany, Cyprus and United Kingdom. Four of them have been working previously together on a common project.

We have designed the three years project around teachers training, transnational mobilities and learning workshop and teacher’s seminars.

During the first year of the project (2015/2016), there will be one course per term. Each school will send at least two teachers who will have to develop a seminar in their own school about what they learnt. The courses are held in UK, Cyprus and France, and are related to problem based learning, entrepreneurship and developing creative thinking. 

During the second (2016/2017) and third (2017/2018) years of the project we will develop six tasks in total, working on skills closely linked to employability (creativity, problem solving, creative thinking, communication, well being, respect, team, workorganisation, health). There will be seven transnational meetings in which pupils travelling from all the schools will work on common activities in collaboration with pupils from foreign schools, showing what they have learned with the developed task. Moreover, apart from using these meetings to evaluate and organize the next steps of the project, the hosting teachers will develop a seminar about how to we work a specific key competence.

Through the tasks, pupils will create a pupet using different elements of the traditional dresses of the other countries,;build typical buildings using LEGO, organizing their work to plan how to do it; write a story in collaboration with the other countries and read it to other students; cook a traditional dish of every country and create an exposiction expressing their emotions after listening to traditional songs of all the countries, among others.

Assessment and dissemination are two or our main concerns while doing the project. All the people involved, meaning parents, teachers and pupils, will evaluate and disseminate what has been done through different media.

Concerning the impact, we can envisage the results in two ways. First, the concrete and immediate ones, throughout the two final products we’re going to create (a website with all the resources and a book compelling all the key competences seminars) and, for students and teachers, the use of English in a meaningful way. Then, the invisibles and long terms ones, throughout the improvement of our students’ employability, being made sensitive to creativity, problem solving and critical thinking, emotional intelligence, organization skills, respect of the differences and communication. At the end, this experience should increase for everybody the feeling of being part of the same Europe considering our differences as possibilities to learn better and to be in keeping with today’s society.
